tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out the best way to take care of this period pain.

The approach would be to use an anti inflammatory pain reliever to not only reduce the pain, but reduce the amount of bleeding.

It is always better to take the pills day before the period starts to prevent the pain from building up.

With this approach in mind, see what is recommended below.

collapsable.title: Relieving Pain click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): 

Start taking this the day before your period  starts, and continue for the first few days of the period.

Take the tablets regularly, for 2-3 days each period, rather than 'now and then' when pain builds up (taking as-needed use is not adequate for most people).    

If taken early and in prescription strength (see "know this" for dosing), they are extremely successful in alleviating menstrual pain.

A good example is ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin.

 

Can't take NSAIDS?    

Take a combination pill of Acetaminophen 500 mg (Pain reliever), Pamabrom 25mg (diuretic), Pyrilamine maleate 15 mg (antihistamine), Caffeine.    

Examples are Midol®, Pamprin®, Premsyn PMS.   

These are useful if you experience significant bloating, headache and water retention.    

Take midol® if the main thing is a headache.

Take Pamprin® if the main concern is feeling bloated.

collapsable.title: Bloated? headaches? click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Midol if mainly headaches.

Pamprin if mainly bloating.

collapsable.title: Worth trying click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Apply a heating pad to your lower belly area, below the belly button.
     
  • Take warm showers or baths.
     
  • Keep your legs raised while lying down.
     
  • Lie on the side with your knees bent.
     
  • Do light circular massage with your fingertips around your lower belly area.
     
  • Do low-fat vegetarian diet at least for now.
     
  • Cut back on salt to help prevent water retention.

    Water retention can lead to breast tenderness; swelling of your feet, ankles, and hands; and headaches.
     
  • Try vitamin B6, calcium, and magnesium supplements.
     
  • Now is a good time to take fish oil.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/06/2016

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to collapse contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.top_header:
Ewe,
Let's get something for this cold.

There is no cure for the common cold.
What you can do is:

  • take care of the symptoms with over-the-counter medications

  • reduce it's ability to limit your daily activities

  • reduce the duration of the cold

  • prevent any complications.
tabs.header: The most common symptoms of a cold are listed below. Choose what you are experiencing and see what we recommend.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a cold:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let me recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the common cold. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.
mode.2: Looking for something to prevent or boost your resistance to the cold?
mode.3:
All the symptoms?
You must have this cold really bad.

Your best bet would be to visit the nearest urgent care clinic. If you don't think so, here is what we recommend to use over-the-counter.

Talk about Antihistamine, cough, decongestant and pain relief
mode.4: Selection requires an antihistamine.
mode.5: You will need a decongestant for this stuffy nose.
mode.6: Need a pain reliever to take care of this.
mode.7: Need to quiet the cough and relieve anychest congestion.
mode.8: You will need an antihistamine and a decongestant.
mode.9: Selection require an antihistamine and a pain reliever.
mode.10: Symptoms require an antihistamine and a Cough relief medication.
mode.11: Symptoms will require an antihistamine, decongestant and pain reliever.
mode.12: Symptoms require an antihistamine, decongestant, Cough relief relief medications.
mode.13: Symptoms require an antihistamine, cough and pain relievers.
mode.14:
You must have this cold really bad.

Your best bet would be to visit the nearest urgent care clinic. If you don't think so, here is what we recommend to use over-the-counter.
mode.15: Selections require a decongestant and pain relief medications
mode.16: Will need a decongestant and something for cough/congestion relief.
mode.17: You will need a decongestant, pain and Cough relief medications.
mode.18: Symptoms require a Cough relief and pain relief medication.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 12:16:am
mode_not.content2: We can help you compare over the counter multi-symptom cold medications that will work best for you if you need help with that.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
Definitely:    ​

  • Wash the hands often.
  • Use alcohol-based hand sanitizers if water is not available.
  • If your school-age child sneezes, have him or her wash hands immediately. Don't be lazy about this. Just one quick sneeze is enough to make you sick. 

Over-The-Counter Medicines:

We strongly recommend the cold prevention medicines comparison feature of this app. (See link below).

collapsable.title: Decongestants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Start with a decongestant nasal spray.

Prefer nasal spray containing oxymetazoline. These last for up to 12 hours.
Those containing phenylephrine need to be used every 4 to 6 hours.
 

After 3 to 5 days, if you are still congested, switch to pseudoephedrine tablets. Continuing the spray will lead to a cycle of rebounding nasal congestion. Don't be tempted to use the nasal spray for more than 5 days. Take this seriously or you will be in for a nasal congestion ride of your life. How do you know if you are in the rebound phase? If a decongestant nasal spray that used to give you relief for 12 hrs, became 10hrs and now it is 8 hrs. Stop.
 

We do not recommend phenylephrine tablets. Don't waste your money. If you want to breathe at night, go to the pharmacy counter and ask for pseudoephedrine tablets. Take a government issued ID with you.

If you can't take pseudoephedrine tablets or the congestion is not so bad, continue with saline nasal spray.

Before we continue, our sponsor would like to share something we think you should know about.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
The first generation antihistamines - chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine or diphenhydramine work better for cold. They will make you sleepy, however.

Do not use non-sedating antihistamines like Claritin, Allegra or Zyrtec when it comes to cold. They are only useful in allergy situations.

If you have other symptoms, look for multisymptom medications with chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine,  diphenhydramine or doxylamine.

Use the "FYI" button below for a good way to compare multisymptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Pain / Fever reducer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Prefer acetaminophen if what you are experiencing is mainly headache along with other cold symptoms like runny nose and nasal congestion.
 

Prefer ibuprofen or naproxen if muscle ache and pain, sinus pain or sinus pressure due to inflamed sinuses.
These have anti-inflammatory properties. Unlike acetaminophen.

collapsable.title: Cough Relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Suppressing the cough    

Use a cough suppressant if:

  • this cough is keeping you up at night 
  • this is a dry cough with no mucus being produced. 
  • this cough is giving you chest pain.     

If none of these, stay away from a cough suppressant.    ​

Postnasal drip (mucus dripping to the back of the throat) is causing most of the coughing by triggering the cough reflex. This is the body's attempt to clear the air passages and prevent mucus from getting to the lungs. If you take a cough suppressant, this preventive mechanism is suppressed leading to a higher potential for secondary upper respiratory tract infections.

Dextromethorphan is the cough suppressant available besides menthol in cough drops. There are different formulations, so see "FYI" below for how to choose a good cough suppressant that will work best for you.

Expectorant    

With time, mucus accumulates in the sinuses and nasal passages. This can become thick reducing its flow.

Mucus in the body should be thin and flow easily as it moistens the lining of the sinuses, respiratory tract and remove bacteria, viruses, dust, pollen and other foreign substances.
 

Thick mucus is bad because it traps bacteria, viruses and dirt and does not flow easily and quickly enough for the body to get rid of it either by swallowing it or coughing it up and out.
 

An expectorant will break up, loosen and thin the mucus making it flow more easily for you to expectorate (bring it up and out).    
 

Must drink a lot of water for it to work effectively.

Guaifenesin is the most common expectorant.   

 

Combination or not?

Get a combination (Guaifenesin DM) if you have chest congestion and coughing is getting violent or giving you chest pain.

You will experience this during the last stage of the cold because the mucus has dried up triggering the cough reflex and it is not flowing leading to coughing spells.

Guaifenesin with drinking a lot of water will break this up and get the mucus flowing again while dextromethorphan will help control the coughing spells until the mucus stops triggering this cough reflex.

collapsable.title: Multi-Symptom click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Choosing a multi-symptoms cold medicine    ​

The best thing to do is to use the comparison feature of this app. (See link below).    

What to look out for:    ​

  • Make sure other medicine you are taking does not contain acetaminophen. Most multi-symptom will contain acetaminophen.
  • Don't expect them to relieve nasal congestion even if it says so on the box. Except you buy the ones kept behind the pharmacy counter.
  • We don't really recommend these because cold comes in different stages. You have to treat the symptom at that stage or you are wasting your money. For instance, the last stage is usually the coughing and chest congestion phase. Buying a multisymptom with cough suppressants or expectorants earlier, may be a waste of money.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Invest in a humidifier

The air is dry which in turn dries up the nasal passages and need to be moisturized.

We recommend cool mist.    

Warm mist is too dangerous especially if you have children in the house. Moreover, by the time the moisture gets from the air to your nasal passages, it is already cold.

Warm mist is also more expensive.

If you really need a warm mist, put your head over a bowl of hot water to inhale the vapors. Or better yet, take a hot shower. 

High vitamin and mineral concentrations

Take any of the high vitamin and mineral containing tablets or packets that you dissolve in water before drinking. Examples include  Airborne® or Emergency C®.
These work 50% of the time to reduce the severity of the cold symptoms.

But stay away from the ones you spray in your mouth. Some taste like urine. The taste of zinc can be hard to mask.

Drink plenty of water

More so if you have chest congestion. You need to thin the mucus so it will keep moving.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Ewe,
Let's figure out something over the counter for this headache.

Tap on the type of headache you think you are experiencing and see what is recommended to use over the counter.
abuttons:
Tension

Dull, pressure-like pain.
Like a tight band around my head

Migraine

Pulsating, throbbing pain
Very sensitive to light, sound

Sinus

Pain, pressure in forehead
Worse when I bend down

Others

Hangover, premenstrual.
